ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned basic acting techniques and how to perform better using my past experience and present self.
I learned a lot of acting concepts that were easy to absorb and put into practice through coursework.
I learned more about various acting teachers and techniques and used this knowledge and our in and out of class work to better my acting skills.

I learned a lot in this course! I feel that I developed an understanding of how to approach an acting role and the thought processes of the founding practitioners of modern theater. I do feel that I became a better actress in this class.
Learned abut different acting theories and teachings. Expanded my acting techniques and worked on forming a creative process.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was an amazing class. I liked how small it was. There was a lot of individual attention and small group interactions, which I much prefer to larger lecture classes.

I think the resources that Hal picked to study from were diverse and extremely relevant to what we put into practice in class. I think some of the work felt unclear as to how to garner a good grade so more transparency would be helpful.

I loved all the readings we did and our scene and monologue work. I would have liked more time working on our final scenes and discussing the readings in more depth. Sometimes it felt like there were too many assignments that we didnt get to spend enough time on all of them. We received very clear feedback on all assignments, though, which was super helpful.

Strengths: Variety in class styles (class discussions, activities, improvisations, rehearsals), good readings; fun, exciting class, lots of personal feedback

Weaknesses: Sometimes a bit slow (for example, we only did 3 acting presentations), beginning of the semester was a bit slow and end was a bit rushed; so I guess, better course pacing. I would love to have more instruction on the similarities and differences in the teachings of Hagen, Stanislavski, and Gillett; sometimes, they blended together for me.

Overall, an enjoyable class. I really liked doing the readings of famous acting teachers, like Hagen and Stanislavski. It was nice being able to work on scenes and monologues. One weakness would be the timing of the course. I feel like we spent too much time on monologues and our senes and didn't get enough time for the final project.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if someone is interested in performance this is a fantastic class to obtain basic skills. It is also great for meeting other people involved in theater at Yale.
I would definitely recommend for any aspiring actors. Its a great jumping off point for learning the basics and the fundamental theorists on the subject.
If you are interested in theater and acting specifically, I would! You can learn a lot and develop your skill set in this class, and Hal is a great instructor.
Yes I would! Especially for students with no prior acting experience. Hal is great!

Yes I would. If you haven't taken an acting class before, it gives a nice foundation and an opportunity to work on scenes. If you took acting in high school, it might feel repetitive and a little slow. Overall is pretty fun, not too much work, and gives a good base understanding of acting techniques and practices.
